comments.commentBody: After reading about the amount of funds these leagues and teams have on hand, I don't see myself throwing any more money in the jar when the kids are camped out outside the supermarket exit seeking donations or selling useless Omaha steak coupons.
Let's make America great again.

The best thing any organization can do is assume that *someone* will be tempted to steal, given the opportunity. Proactively reducing opportunities for theft is far better than decrying modern moral decay afterward. Dividing up financial duties and oversight is a good start.

If theft is immoral, then so is creating the lure to steal by setting out piles of money with a sign effectively saying, "No one will notice if you steal this, but please don't." The simple truth of human nature is that most people have some vulnerability to stealing, given the right mix of character and situation. You can't tell by looking at them -- maybe not even by looking in the mirror.

I think this article demonstrates convincingly that if corporations are indeed people, then they surely need the same scrupulous external oversight and penalties to reduce their potential to cheat the society around them. A self-regulating market is as naive as the dream of true communism. Only a robust, regulated government vying on equal terms with a robust, regulated market can neutalize each other's intrinsic human flaws.

Somewhere along the line. Some people blame the 1960s. Some blame the Republicans since Reagan. Some blame the liberals. Some will blame the decade of greed during Reagan years. Some will blame Barack Obama.

The American apple-pie 1950s were during the worst years of the Communist fears. It must be the Communists. Some now blame the NRA.

Sounds simple to me, its the overhyped greed of the pure capitalists who have tried to eliminate all regulatory agencies so they can continue to ransack the economy and the American people. Why not steal your share too, small town America; everyone else is getting away with it. No banker has gone to jail. It's one big soup pot; throw everything in and stir like crazy.
You do realize that soccer is a year 'round sport in most of the world, yes?

Here is more on the so-called RICO action.

https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/2902722-06-23-16-LTR-to-Smith-Re...

Particularly read the final paragraph about harassment ... Constitutional crisis ... dangerous and uncharted territory.
It's worth mentioning that Murray and Raonic were not that far apart today. There was only one service break in three sets.
Big deal, she smashed a racket. If she had smacked a line judge with it I could see you point.
One of her white opponents was also fined, btw. Game changer for your insightful worldview analogy, I guess. Go Serena!

Watching Wimbledon this year was a pleasure, as always. And especially now, seeing people of all races behaving like civilized, sporting human beings (except Serena Williams, who everyone is crowning the Greatest and a Wonderful Human Being; she was fined $10,000 for unsportsmanlike conduct at this Wimbledon; she's fine when she's winning, but quite the opposite otherwise; she could learn a lot from her intelligent, poised, funny, dignified and unfailing sportsmanlike sister) was heart-warming. It's too bad it isn't a microcosm of the real world.
Congratulations, Andy!! You were great!!

In my day, to win a Grand Slam meant to win in a single season all the major opens, which only the greatest have ever done. That's what grand slam, a term from bridge means — to win all the tricks in a hand.

The hyperbole of sports reporting, verging far too often on adolescent hysteria, nestling cosily in the pocket of the marketeers and the shameless merchants of spin, does no service to the game of tennis or any other.

And when Scotland secedes from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, the Poms won't even be able to claim that Murray is a Brit.

I find it hard to imagine what Andy Murray must now mean to the town of Dunblane, given what happened there in 1996, especially as he was in the school on that terrible March day when Thomas Hamilton murdered so many. Dunblane's name was in danger of only being associated with tragedy but Andy has somehow alleviated that. What a wonderful achievement.

I like a player who not only performs beautifully in most matches and works incredibly hard off court, but is outspoken in his support of his female colleagues and progressive and kind in his views. He was the first top male player to hire a female coach (mauresmo) and his ranking climbed to #2 when he worked with her, a fact he pointed out to media members who dissed her.

Moops..."the greatest champion to ever hold a tennis racquet" ... Next you'll write how much you respect all the commentators on ESPN and the greedy and smug - in Tennis Magazine---Chrissie.

It's the racquet, the sun, the wind, the noise, the cameras, the clothes, the bags and the money.

It's all about the money
Great comment NYC Father! Couldn't have said it better myself.
Well done, Andy.  But don't forget --- next time you see Querrey, you owe him a beer :-)

I was glad to see Murray win again. In a way it was like a first Wimbledon win, because the last win was for the UK. And he's more fun to watch now. He's reached a higher skill level and is more emotionally mature. Good on you Andy. Good luck at the US Open. But if Nadal is healthy, I have to pull for Rafa!

A bit like McEnroe.  But he has the reputation of being a decent, agreeable and modest individual off court. Speaking of JM, it must have utterly galled him to say that mens' tennis in Canada was in better shape than the US.

It’s a European style system, not innocent until proven guilty as US, but guilty until proven innocent. Thus if prosecutor can not form a case charges dropped. Widely used in the world, perhaps more common than British model.

Hillary as China sees her is much like the commentary found in American media, kinder on positive and negative sides if anything.

The interest question is how she will perceive US-Chinese relations in her probable role as POTUS. Statements as candidate seeking votes carry little weight, but her echoing Pres. Obama on the Pivot to Asia will be critical. The American links to Asia heavily Military China’s heavily Economic the resulting scenario dangerous.

Does the world need a Cold-War-II? Winston Churchill once advised that it is always better to “jaw-jaw” than to “war-war,” meaning diplomacy is preferable to conflict. Hopefully HRC is of that school, but that may be debatable.
The problem being China difficult to frighten and like America in an assertive mood.

And because these armed "militia members" demonstrated cowardice when they should have been using their firearms to uphold law and order, they should be dishonorably discharged from the "Texas Militia" and summarily disarmed.
Weren't these open carry people some of the same people that were convinced that "Obama" was going to have the military "take over" Texas earlier in the year?  They must be afraid to sleep at night.
They were there to protest the Black Lives Matter group's existence. They weren't protesting the killing of citizens by the police.

There is a time and place for everything. One has the legal right to do a lot of things in public that are both stupid and offensive. And in this case, dangerous. These brave "armed citizens", who thought it a good idea to come armed to a civil rights demonstration over people getting shot, are fortunate that they themselves were not shot.

NRA propaganda tells us that in the event of a mass shooter, having "good guys with guns" will neutralize the bad guy with a gun. On that theory, all of these brave armed citizens should have run toward the gunfire, taken up positions, and returned the fire Instead, they pretty much all ran away from the gunfire. So much for the NRA fairy tales. All these brave armed citizens accomplished was distraction of already highly stressed police forces.
A league used to be 3 miles...  So I believe the "20K leagues" refers to the distance the Nautilus traveled underwater...
Help me here. The deepest place in the ocean, the Mariana Trench is a bit more than 36,200' below sea level. Wait! The distance traveled under the sea not the depth. Is my face REDs.

Pleasant little Monday with a hint of bite. WALTZ OFF WITH was perfectly clued, popped in my head instantly and it's not that commonly used.  Anybody like old books? Might I suggest checking out text printed on handmade BIRCHbark books from the early last century. My wife has one of them from an icon of California history Charles Lummis. Hold history in your hands! On another note, how deep is 20,000 leagues?
I've read that nowadays, Canadians waver between saying ZEE and ZED.  Not so?
Canadians are inconsistent.  Ever try to buy a tyre for your car up there?
It seems that the zed should get more than 10 points in Canada, because it is less frequently utilised there.

and Elke
OH GEE- WAY up North of the 49thparallel, the Scrabble 10pointer is ZEd , not ZEE. So was stuck on a Monday for a while.
On the other hand , SNEE as in snickerSNEE , brought back happy memories of an unforgettable performance of Gilbert & Sullivan's The Mikado in Stratford, Ontario :
https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Mikado/The_criminal_cried_as_he_dropp...

I realize the schedule of the puzzles was fixed some time ago, but the timing of this WAR OF WORDS is unfortunate.
Going back to listening to "three little maids" et alii .

The range of labor market indicators show the US economy is at full employment.

As the JOLT data and anecdotal reports indicate, the unemployment that remains is structural, not cyclical. There is a skills-mismatch.

This requires a fiscal, not monetary, response through better access to higher education and vocational programs.

The deflationary effect coming from a supply-driven collapse in energy prices and one-time Medicare and Medicaid reductions in reimbursement rates are transitory.

The year over year core PCE is just under the Fed's inflation target, but the annualized quarterly PCE inflation data is just over the target.

Hard to argue we don't have full employment and price stability relative to historical standards.

What is new is a prolonged period of negative real interest rates in the US given these conditions.

It has submerged the lower boundary on the cost of capital for marginal productive capacity below a 0% return, hurting productivity.

It is causing chaos around the globe as much weaker developed market economies far more dependent on trade are being forced to depreciate their currencies using negative nominal rates in a crisis response.

That undermines confidence and further reallocates capital to unproductive endeavors.

The central banks, particularly in the US, were the heroes post-Crisis.

Yet they risk their well-earned credibility if they don't act as a counter-cyclical and instead decide to replace market-based capital decisions.
A league used to be 3 miles...  So I believe the "20K leagues" refers to the distance the Nautilus traveled underwater...
I think the Black Lives Matter people should carry assault rifles in Texas.  Then let's see if the NRA starts supporting gun control.
Did Reagan, St. Ronnie, really say this?  Then why isn't it plastered in every gun shop?  Why isn't it posted in every NRA publication?

He said that before WW-2 overcapitalized our firearms manufacturing industry, which subsequently grew into the economic behemoth that it is today.

The simple fact is firearms (their ammunition especially) are as immensely profitable as throw-away pens and throw-away razor blades. That's because thrown-away people aren't part of the cost equation thanks to a grant of blanket immunity granted gun manufacturers by Congress.

“I have never believed in the general practice of carrying weapons,” said NRA President Karl T. Frederick, a 1920 Olympic gold-medal winner for marksmanship who became a lawyer, praising state gun control laws in Congress. He testified before the 1938 federal gun control law passed. “I do not believe in the general promiscuous toting of guns. I think it should be sharply restricted and only under licenses.”

“There’s no reason why on the street today a citizen should be carrying loaded weapons,” said California Gov. Ronald Reagan in May 1967, after two dozen Black Panther Party members walked into the California Statehouse carrying rifles to protest a gun-control bill. Reagan said guns were “a ridiculous way to solve problems that have to be solved among people of good will.”

“You do know that I am a member of the NRA and my position on the right to bear arms is well known,” Reagan said, speaking out in support of the 1994 Brady bill to create new background checks and a waiting period for gun buyers. “But I want you to know something else, and I am going to say it in clear, unmistakable language: I support the Brady Bill and I urge Congress to enact it without further delay.”

http://www.salon.com/2013/01/23/7_uncovered_quotes_that_reveal_just_how_...
